required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Postoperative Peripheral Nerve Stimulation for Management of Post-amputation Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Postoperative Percutaneous Peripheral Nerve Stimulation on Acute and Chronic Amputation Pain

lead_sponsor.agency: Hunter Holmes Mcguire Veteran Affairs Medical Center

clinical_study.source: Hunter Holmes Mcguire Veteran Affairs Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: Limb loss is frequently associated with postamputation pain that can be challenging to treat and often involves opioids. Advances in the field of neuromodulation has led to development of an intentionally reversible percutaneous peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) system that has had promising results when treating chronic postamputation pain. PNS may offer sustained pain relief even after the treatment period has ended. Currently, there is no convincing evidence regarding the role of PNS in the acute postoperative period, which may be a critical time to control pain as those with higher pain appear to be at higher risk for developing persistent post-procedural pain. The investigators of this study aim to evaluate the feasibility and effects of PNS in the acute postoperative period and determine the feasibility of completing a randomized controlled treatment outcome study.

detailed_description.textblock:
16 patients with new nontraumatic transfemoral or transtibial amputation will be enrolled in the study
Having met inclusion criteria, the patients will be randomized to experimental or control groups
Patients in the experimental group undergo placement of PNS leads within 7 days of amputation surgery
Patients in both groups will be treated with standard pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic pain therapies and evaluated weekly for 8 weeks, then at 3, 6, and 12 months postamputation

primary_outcome.description: Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their PLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their RLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their PLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their RLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their PLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their RLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Preop, Hospital Discharge, Weeks 1-4, Weeks 5-8, Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The number of subjects prescribed any opioid medication and any dose. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperative, Hospital discharge, Weeks 1-4, Weeks 5-8, and Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Opioid consumption (daily OME) over time was collected for all subjects.

FIM mobility subscores were recorded by a physical therapist to measure the ability to walk, use a wheelchair, transfer to tub/shower, transfer to toilet, and mobility in bed, chair, and wheelchair. Scores range from "1" = subject requires total assistance for the task to "7" = complete independence. A higher score is better.

Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate how much pain has interfered with daily activities over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0" = no interference to "10" = completely interferes with activities. A lower score is better.

Self-report measure PGIC reflects a patient's belief about the efficacy of treatment. PGIC is a 7 point scale depicting a patient's rating of overall improvement. Patients rate their change as 1 = "very much improved," 2 = "much improved," 3 = "minimally improved," 4 = "no change," 5 = "minimally worse," 6 = "much worse," or 7 = "very much worse." A lower score is better.

Pain catastrophizing is the tendency to magnify the threat value of a pain stimulus and to feel helpless in the presence of pain. This is further characterized by the inability to prevent or inhibit pain-related thoughts surrounding a painful event. Pain catastrophizing affects how individuals experience pain. The PCS is a 13-item inventory of statements in which the subject is asked to rate the degree to which they agree, on a scale of "0" = not at all to "4" = all the time. The responses for each item are added for a total PCS score (range 0-52). A lower score is better.

The PDI is designed to measure the degree to which aspects of life are disrupted by chronic pain. The impact of pain on various aspects of life (e.g. family/home responsibilities, recreation, social activity, occupation, sexual behavior, self-care, and life-support activities) are recorded on a 10-point scale from "0" = no disability to "10" = worst disability. The sum of scores is recorded for a total PDI score (range 0-70). A lower score is better.
Percent of Group that was readmitted to the hospital within 30 days following hospital discharge.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Number of days from surgery to discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Hospital LOS was calculated from day of surgery to day of discharge from inpatient hospital ward to rehabilitation facility.

arm_group.description: Standard medical therapy and 30 to 60 days of peripheral nerve stimulation starting within 7 days after surgery

intervention.description: Up to 60 days of peripheral nerve stimulation
Medications, physical therapy, or other pain treatments

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Nontraumatic transfemoral (above-the-knee) or transtibial (below-the-knee) amputation
- Presence of postamputation pain rated at least 4 or more
Exclusion Criteria:
- Beck Depression Inventory score greater than 20
- Systemic infection
- Immunocompromised or taking immunosuppressive medications
- Implanted electronic device
- Pregnancy
- Previous allergy to skin contact materials and/or anesthetic agent
- Altered mental status
- Inability to provide informed consent

overall_official.affiliation: Hunter Holmes McGuire VA Medical Center

facility.name: Hunter Holmes McGuire VA Medical Center

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Standard medical therapy and 30 to 60 days of peripheral nerve stimulation starting within 7 days after surgery Peripheral nerve stimulation: Up to 60 days of peripheral nerve stimulation Standard Medical Therapy: Medications, physical therapy, or other pain treatments

group.title: Standard Medical Therapy (SMT)
group.description: Standard medical therapy only Standard Medical Therapy: Medications, physical therapy, or other pain treatments

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Up to 60 days of PNS starting within 7 days after major lower limb amputation surgery. Subjects also received standard medical therapy (SMT). SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Average Phantom Limb Pain (PLP) Score
outcome.description: Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate their PLP over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0"=no pain to "10"=worst pain they have ever experienced. A lower score is better. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.
outcome.population: Subjects who completed up to 60 days of peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) and standard medical therapy (SMT) or (SMT) only.

outcome.title: Number Taking Opioids
outcome.description: The number of subjects prescribed any opioid medication and any dose. Data from Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8 were averaged to obtain a numerical score for these time points.
outcome.time_frame: Preop, Hospital Discharge, Weeks 1-4, Weeks 5-8, Week 12
outcome.population: Between Weeks 1-4 and Weeks 5-8, three subjects in the PNS Group terminated due to unrelated medical events (2) or withdrew consent (1). After Week 12, two subjects in the Control Group terminated due to unrelated medical events or withdrew consent (data for one subject was collected prior to withdrawal).

group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

measure.title: Functional Independence Measure (FIM) Scores
measure.description: FIM mobility subscores were recorded by a physical therapist to measure the ability to walk, use a wheelchair, transfer to tub/shower, transfer to toilet, and mobility in bed, chair, and wheelchair. Scores range from "1" = subject requires total assistance for the task to "7" = complete independence. A higher score is better.

outcome.title: Pain Interference
outcome.description: Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate how much pain has interfered with daily activities over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0" = no interference to "10" = completely interferes with activities. A lower score is better.
outcome.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Up to 60 days of PNS starting within 7 days after major lower limb amputation surgery. Subjects also received standard medical therapy (SMT). SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

measure.title: Pain Interference
measure.description: Using the Brief Pain Inventory-Short Form (BPI-SF) questionnaire, subjects were asked to rate how much pain has interfered with daily activities over the past 24 hours on a scale of "0" = no interference to "10" = completely interferes with activities. A lower score is better.
measure.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

outcome.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC)
outcome.description: Self-report measure PGIC reflects a patient's belief about the efficacy of treatment. PGIC is a 7 point scale depicting a patient's rating of overall improvement. Patients rate their change as 1 = "very much improved," 2 = "much improved," 3 = "minimally improved," 4 = "no change," 5 = "minimally worse," 6 = "much worse," or 7 = "very much worse." A lower score is better.
outcome.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Up to 60 days of PNS starting within 7 days after major lower limb amputation surgery. Subjects also received standard medical therapy (SMT). SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

measure.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC)
measure.description: Self-report measure PGIC reflects a patient's belief about the efficacy of treatment. PGIC is a 7 point scale depicting a patient's rating of overall improvement. Patients rate their change as 1 = "very much improved," 2 = "much improved," 3 = "minimally improved," 4 = "no change," 5 = "minimally worse," 6 = "much worse," or 7 = "very much worse." A lower score is better.
measure.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

outcome.title: Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS)
outcome.description: Pain catastrophizing is the tendency to magnify the threat value of a pain stimulus and to feel helpless in the presence of pain. This is further characterized by the inability to prevent or inhibit pain-related thoughts surrounding a painful event. Pain catastrophizing affects how individuals experience pain. The PCS is a 13-item inventory of statements in which the subject is asked to rate the degree to which they agree, on a scale of "0" = not at all to "4" = all the time. The responses for each item are added for a total PCS score (range 0-52). A lower score is better.
outcome.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Up to 60 days of PNS starting within 7 days after major lower limb amputation surgery. Subjects also received standard medical therapy (SMT). SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

measure.title: Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS)
measure.description: Pain catastrophizing is the tendency to magnify the threat value of a pain stimulus and to feel helpless in the presence of pain. This is further characterized by the inability to prevent or inhibit pain-related thoughts surrounding a painful event. Pain catastrophizing affects how individuals experience pain. The PCS is a 13-item inventory of statements in which the subject is asked to rate the degree to which they agree, on a scale of "0" = not at all to "4" = all the time. The responses for each item are added for a total PCS score (range 0-52). A lower score is better.
measure.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

outcome.title: Pain Disability Index (PDI)
outcome.description: The PDI is designed to measure the degree to which aspects of life are disrupted by chronic pain. The impact of pain on various aspects of life (e.g. family/home responsibilities, recreation, social activity, occupation, sexual behavior, self-care, and life-support activities) are recorded on a 10-point scale from "0" = no disability to "10" = worst disability. The sum of scores is recorded for a total PDI score (range 0-70). A lower score is better.
outcome.population: Subjects who were enrolled in the study and for whom this data was collected.

measure.description: The PDI is designed to measure the degree to which aspects of life are disrupted by chronic pain. The impact of pain on various aspects of life (e.g. family/home responsibilities, recreation, social activity, occupation, sexual behavior, self-care, and life-support activities) are recorded on a 10-point scale from "0" = no disability to "10" = worst disability. The sum of scores is recorded for a total PDI score (range 0-70). A lower score is better.

outcome.title: 30-day Readmission Rate
outcome.description: Percent of Group that was readmitted to the hospital within 30 days following hospital discharge.

measure.description: Percent of Group that was readmitted to the hospital within 30 days following hospital discharge.

outcome.title: Hospital Length of Stay (LOS)
outcome.description: Hospital LOS was calculated from day of surgery to day of discharge from inpatient hospital ward to rehabilitation facility.
outcome.time_frame: Number of days from surgery to discharge

reported_events.time_frame: Week 4 and Week 8, Month 3, Month 6, and Month 12
reported_events.desc: Subjects in the Control Group were not at risk for PNS Lead Reimplantation because they did not undergo implantation of any peripheral nerve stimulator leads. Other [Not Including Serious] Adverse Events were not monitored/assessed in the Control Arm/Group.

group.title: Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS)
group.description: Up to 60 days of PNS starting within 7 days after major lower limb amputation surgery. Subjects also received standard medical therapy (SMT). SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

group.title: Control
group.description: Subjects received SMT only after major lower limb amputation surgery. SMT is defined as pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, or other therapies.

event.description: Two subjects in the PNS group required reimplantation of PNS leads due to dislodgement. No suspected lead fractures were observed during the treatment period or lead removal.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Several participants underwent unanticipated amputation revisions, which has the potential to contribute to worsening pain and the need for increased opioids, which may significantly confound results. Subjects were instructed to use the device continuously, and the effects of PNS therapy may be impacted by the number of hours the device was utilized by the patient. Variations in subject compliance with device usage may impact outcomes.

point_of_contact.organization: Central Virginia Veterans Affairs Health Care System
